prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
############################ # IR20551 HCO+ v2=1f J=4-3 # ############################
Basic observing parameters: For our observations of all molecular transition lines, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: The observed peak flux of HCN v2=1f J=4-3 emission line for IRAS 20551-4250 is 4 mJy (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013b). For IRAS 20551-4250, the HCO+/HCN J=4-3 and HNC/HCN J=4-3 flux ratios at v=0 are 1.4 and 0.7, respectively (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013b). If HCO+ and HNC are vibrationally-excited to v2=1f in a similar way to HCN (case 1), then the HCO+/HCN v2=1f J=4-3 and HNC/HCN v2=1f J=4-3 flux ratios are expected to be 1.4 and 0.7, respectively. Namely, the expected peak flux of HCO+ v2=1f J=4-3 is 5.5 mJy, and that of HNC v2=1f J=4-3 is 3 mJy. If HCN is more preferentially vibrationally-excited by infrared radiative pumping than HCO+ and HNC (case 2), then the HCO+/HCN v2=1f J=4-3 and HNC/HCN v2=1f J=4-3 flux ratios are expected to be <1.4 and <0.7, respectively. To clearly distinguish between case 1 and 2, we set the required exposure time to achieve 5 sigma for the emission peak flux in case 1. If the emission lines are present with line width of 100-200 km/s in FWHM (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013b), at least several consecutive pixels should show flux excess for the 20 km/s velocity resolution. The detection significance of the emission lines, based on Gaussian fits and/or moment 0 maps, will be >10 in case 1. If we obtain no significant detection (<3 sigma) for HCO+ and HNC v2=1f J=4-3 lines in case 2, we can clearly differentiate the case 2 from case 1, and so can provide very strong observational constraints on whether infrared radiative pumping works in a similar manner for HCN, HCO+, and HNC, or works effectively only for HCN. This distinction is crucial to obtain an answer to the question of whether the infrared radiative pumping mechanism indeed enhances HCN emission fluxes in AGNs.
Since the expected peak flux of HCO+ v2=1f J=4-3 is 5.5 mJy in case 1, the requested 1 sigma noise level for 5 sigma detection is 1.1 mJy. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that the required observing time will be 0.8 hr to achieve 1 sigma noise of 1.1 mJy for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HCO+ v2=1f J=4-3 and HCO+ J=4-3 + HCN v2=1f J=4-3 lines at the same time to better constrain the flux ratios between HCO+ v2=1f J=4-3 and HCN v2=1f J=4-3, as well as between HCO+ v2=1f J=4-3 and HCO+ v=0 J=4-3. In LSB, we will use two spectral windows to cover continuum emission and H13CN J=4-3 (rest frequency = 345.3 GHz) + HC15N J=4-3 (344.2 GHz) lines.
Continuum observation in LSB is important to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c).
H13CN and HC15N J=4-3 emission lines are expected to be optically-thin. Comparison of the H13CN and HC15N J=4-3 line fluxes with HCN J=4-3 line flux can be used to confirm whether the HCN J=4-3 line is optically-thick or not. This optical depth information for the HCN J=4-3 (v=0) line is crucial to quantitatively estimate the role of the infrared radiative pumping for HCN excitation, based on the flux comparison of the HCN v2=1f J=4-3 and HCN v=0 J=4-3 emission lines (Sakamoto et al. 2010).
These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

########################### # IR20551 HNC v2=1f J=4-3 # ###########################
Basic observing parameters: For our observations of all molecular transition lines, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: The expected HNC v2=1f J=4-3 peak flux in case 1 is 3 mJy (see our description above). The requested 1 sigma noise level for 5 sigma detection is 0.6 mJy. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that the required observing time will be 1.4 hr for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC v2=1f J=4-3 and HNC J=4-3 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). Continuum spectral index is useful to understand the physical origin of the continuum emission.
These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

################################ # IR20551 HCN/HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 # ################################
Basic observing parameters: For our observations of all molecular transition lines, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: We need both HCN v2=1f J=3-2 and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 data, which can be taken simultaneously using ALMA.
Based on our ALMA Cycle 0 data, we have information of the HCN J=4-3 (v=0) peak flux with 50 mJy (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013b). When HCN excitation is thermal at up to J=4-3, the HCN J=3-2 (v=0) peak flux is 9/16 of the HCN J=4-3 peak flux. When HCN J=4-3 is sub-thermally excited, the HCN J=3-2 peak flux is larger than 9/16 of the HCN J=4-3 peak flux. Assuming similar HCN v2=1f to v=0 flux ratios between J=4-3 and J=3-2, the expected HCN v2=1f J=3-2 flux is >2.5 mJy. In case 1, the expected HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 flux is >3.0 mJy.
On the other hand, it is observationally well known that the infrared 8-1000 micron and HCN J=1-0 luminosity (flux) from dusty active galaxies are correlated (Gao & Solomon 2004; Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013c). From the infrared luminosity (flux) of IRAS 20551-4250, we can derive the expected HCN J=1-0 luminosity (flux). When we compare this expected HCN J=1-0 luminosity (flux) and the observed HCN J=4-3 luminosity (flux), HCN J=4-3 peak flux is a factor of 2 smaller than that expected from thermal excitation of HCN at up to J=4-3. Namely, the expected HCN v2=1f J=3-2 and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 fluxes are 2.5-5.0 mJy and 3.0-6.0 mJy, respectively, in case 1.
We set the required 1 sigma noise level as 0.6 mJy. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that the required observing time will be 1 hr for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. This is the reason for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

########################### # IR20551 HNC v2=1f J=3-2 # ###########################
Basic observing parameters: For our observations of all molecular transition lines, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: Based on the same assumption for HCN and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines, the expected HNC v2=1f J=3-2 peak flux in case 1 is 1.6-3.2 mJy. We set the required 1 sigma noise as 0.5 mJy. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that the required observing time will be 1.2 hr for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC v2=1f J=3-2 and HNC J=3-2 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). Continuum spectral index is useful to understand the physical origin of the continuum emission.
These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

############################ # NGC 4418 HNC v2=1f J=3-2 # ############################
Basic observing parameters: For our observations of all molecular transition lines, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: HCN v2=1f J=3-2 peak flux is 80 mJy in NGC 4418 (Sakamoto et al. 2010). The observed HNC-to-HCN J=3-2 flux ratio at v=0 is 0.25 (Sakamoto et al. 2010; Costagliola et al. 2013). Thus, the expected peak flux of HNC v2=1f J=3-2 in case 1 is 20 mJy. We set the required 1 sigma noise as 2 mJy. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that the required observing time will be 0.5 hr for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC v2=1f J=3-2 and HNC J=3-2 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). Continuum spectral index is useful to understand the physical origin of the continuum emission. None of these observed frequencies is covered in ALMA Cycle 1 (2012.1.00377.S).
These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to thoroughly investigate the strengths of the vibrationally-excited (v2=1f) rotational (J)-transition lines of HCN, HCO+, and HNC lines, in the two AGN-hosting, narrow-molecular-line, luminous infrared galaxies which show detectable HCN v2=1f J=4-3 emission lines. Our immediate objective is to investigate whether an infrared radiative pumping mechanism indeed works more effectively for HCN than HCO+ and HNC, and is responsible for the enhanced HCN emission observed in AGNs, as proposed by theories. ALMA's high-spatial-resolution (<0.6 arcsec) is crucial to probe only AGN-affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei, with minimum contamination from spatially-extended starburst activity in host galaxies. ALMA's high sensitivity (better than a few mJy noise level) is indispensable to clearly address this issue. Our ultimate scientific goal is to establish a physically-understood reliable tool to separate AGNs from stabursts using bright (sub)millimeter molecular emission lines, which can be used to understand the physical nature of dust/gas-rich infrared luminous galaxies from the local to distant universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This proposal is based on the results of our accepted ALMA Cycle 0 program (2011.0.00020.S) (PI = M. Imanishi). This proposal is closely related also to our accepted ALMA Cycle 1 program (2012.1.00034.S) (PI = M. Imanishi). Our accepted Cycle 1 program focuses on AGN-dominated galaxy nuclei with small molecular line widths, to investigate the ubiquity of the infrared radiative pumping for HCN, through the detection of the vibrationally-excited HCN v2=1f J=3-2 emission lines. This Cycle 2 program aims at quantitative investigation of the role of infrared radiative pumping to various molecules, by targetting for the two AGN hosting galaxies which have shown detectable HCN v2=1f emission lines. Both proposals are complementary to thoroughly understand how the infrared radiative pumping enhances the HCN emission in AGNs in the universe.
